literature_search.user: Find recent research papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus.
literature_search.ai_response:
## Recent papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus

Below are recent, relevant research articles (2023–2025) returned by a literature search for \synaptic plasticity hippocampus.\ For each paper I include the citation, link, a brief summary extracted from the search output, and the article image when available.

---

### 1) **Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons** — Losonczy, Attila (2024)
![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)

- **Journal / Type:** Nature (2024)
- **Link:** [Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9?error=cookies_not_supported&code=99fed048-9696-4c0c-81ab-d1c517d6a190)
- **Summary:** Developed an all-optical approach to monitor dendritic spine-level synaptic weight changes before and after induction of place fields in CA1 pyramidal neurons during navigation. Identifies a temporally asymmetric plasticity kernel and compartment-specific differences (basal vs oblique dendrites) linking synaptic plasticity to rapid emergence of spatial selectivity.

---

### 2) **Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus** — Magee, Jeffrey C. (2025)
![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)

- **Journal / Type:** Nature Neuroscience (2025)
- **Link:** [Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)
- **Summary:** Tracked CA1 place cells over 7 days of learning. Finds progressive stabilization of place cells accompanied by behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP) during formation and retrieval; proposes a cascade-type state model where repeated activation increases neuron-specific likelihood of plasticity rather than requiring fixed long-term weight stabilization.

---

### 3) **CA3 hippocampal synaptic plasticity supports ripple physiology during memory consolidation** — Humeau, Yann (2023)
![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-023-42969-x/MediaObjects/41467_2023_42969_Fig1_HTML.png)

- **Journal / Type:** Nature Communications (2023)
- **Link:** [CA3 hippocampal synaptic plasticity supports ripple physiology during memory consolidation](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-023-42969-x?error=cookies_not_supported&code=3d988442-719f-40d6-a426-2a204ff61a60)
- **Summary:** Uses AMPAR immobilization to block postsynaptic LTP during a spatial memory task; shows hippocampal synaptic plasticity is engaged during consolidation (sleep) and necessary for ripple-dependent rule consolidation. Suggests CA3–CA3 recurrent synaptic plasticity supports ripple generation.

---

### 4) **Synaptic plasticity rules driving representational shifting in the hippocampus** — Sheffield, Mark E. J. (2025)
![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01894-6/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1894_Fig1_HTML.png)

- **Journal / Type:** Nature Neuroscience (2025)
- **Link:** [Synaptic plasticity rules driving representational shifting in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01894-6?error=cookies_not_supported&code=785b48f5-039f-4b2e-8b94-539a066aaf5b)
- **Summary:** Combines computational models and in vivo place-cell data to compare plasticity rules. Concludes behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP) better explains trial-by-trial place-field shifting than Hebbian STDP, with BTSP showing different prevalence and dynamics in CA1 versus CA3.

---

### 5) **Modulation of hippocampal plasticity in learning and memory** — Fuchsberger & Paulsen (review, 2022)
![PubMed image](https://cdn.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/persistent/pubmed-meta-image-v2.jpg)

- **Journal / Type:** Review (PubMed entry, 2022)
- **Link:** [Modulation of hippocampal plasticity in learning and memory (PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35660989/)
- **Summary:** Review covering mechanisms that modulate hippocampal synaptic plasticity and their roles in learning and memory. Useful background and mechanistic context complementing recent experimental results.

---

### 6) **Editorial: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses** — Rossi et al. (2022)
- **Journal / Type:** Frontiers in Cellular Neuroscience (Editorial, 2022)
- **Link (PDF):** [Editorial (open access PDF)](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fncel.2022.980623/pdf)
- **Summary:** Editorial overview of a Research Topic that collects studies on cellular and molecular mechanisms of LTP, LTD, STDP, and homeostatic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses.

---

If you want, I can:
- Retrieve the full text (where publicly available) for any specific paper using the read-paper tool.
- Search for more papers (increase results, narrow by subtopic: BTSP, LTP, CA1 vs CA3, sleep/ripples, molecular mechanisms).
- Provide a short comparative table summarizing species, methods (in vivo imaging, electrophysiology, modeling), and main plasticity mechanism for a selected subset. Which would you like next?

## Summary: NEURON simulation software

### What is **NEURON**
- **NEURON** is a flexible, widely used simulation environment for modeling single neurons and networks of neurons.  
- It emphasizes biophysical realism (morphology, ion channels, synapses) and efficient numerical algorithms tailored to neuronal models.  
- Primary developers: **Michael Hines**, **John W. Moore**, **Ted Carnevale** (historically at Duke & Yale).

---

### Key resources (from the web search)

- **Official site / project pages**
  - **NEURON - Yale** — main project website, news, forum, courses: [neuron.yale.edu](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/)
  - **What is NEURON?** — overview page describing features and advantages: [What is NEURON?](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/what_is_neuron)

- **Documentation**
  - **NEURON documentation / ReadTheDocs** — detailed user & programmer references, installation guides, tutorials, examples: [The NEURON Simulator — nrn.readthedocs.io](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/)

- **Code repository**
  - **GitHub (neuronsimulator/nrn)** — source code, issues, releases: [neuronsimulator/nrn](https://github.com/neuronsimulator/nrn)  
  ![NEURON GitHub image](https://opengraph.githubassets.com/fea22d074c6fe45d3136719a62891126997c893f20b19919abce4ee5ec60ceab/neuronsimulator/nrn)

- **Community & models**
  - **ModelDB** — large repository of published models implemented for NEURON and other simulators: [ModelDB (connected via NEURON pages)](http://modeldb.yale.edu)
  - **NEURON Forum** — active user forum (installation, usage, programming with Python/HOC).

- **Encyclopedic summary**
  - **Wikipedia: Neuron (software)** — historical context, languages used, license: [Neuron (software) — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuron_(software))

---

### Technical highlights
- Languages / APIs:
  - Usable from **Python** or the HOC language; internal code in **C/C++** (and earlier parts in Fortran).
- Platforms:
  - Cross-platform (Linux, macOS, Windows). Wheels and installers available; can run locally, in cloud notebooks (Colab), or on HPC.
- Installation:
  - Typical install via pip: pip3 install neuron (documentation gives platform-specific guidance and Windows/WSL installers).
- Versioning / recent releases:
  - Active development; documentation and release notes available on official site and GitHub (search release tags on the repo).
- MOD files / mechanisms:
  - Mechanisms (NMODL/MOD) historically supported; note that NEURON >= 9.0 has changes (C++ porting) that may require adapting some MOD files — see documentation guide for porting mechanisms.

---

### Useful links (descriptive)

- [NEURON documentation (ReadTheDocs)](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/)

- [ModelDB (NEURON models)](http://modeldb.yale.edu)  
- [NEURON Forum](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/phpBB/)

---

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# If the client supports .all() to fetch everything (with internal paging)
```

software_docs_entitysdk.ai_response:
## List all cell morphologies with the entitysdk

Below is a concise, ready-to-run pattern showing how to list all **CellMorphology** entities using the Open Brain Platform Python package **entitysdk**.

### 1) Install & authenticate (if needed)
- Ensure you have the entitysdk package installed and configured following your project's auth method (token, env vars, or OBI config).  
- The examples below assume you have a configured `Client` instance named `client`.

### 2) Minimal example: retrieve all morphologies
```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.models import CellMorphology

# create or retrieve an authenticated client (example, adjust to your auth)
client = Client()  # configure per your environment

# retrieve all CellMorphology entities
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(morphs)}")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

### 3) Example with limit / paging and quick preview
- The API supports pagination and a `.all()` helper to fetch everything. For very large datasets you may want to fetch by pages or use `limit`.
```python
# fetch a limited number (e.g., first 20)
morphs_page = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=20).all()
print(len(morphs_page))
for m in morphs_page:
    print(m.id, m.name, getattr(m,  rain_region", None))
```

### 4) Show useful fields and assets for each morphology
```python
for m in morphs:
    print(\ID:", m.id)
    print(\Name:", m.name)
    print(\Description:", getattr(m, \description", \"))
    print(\Subject species:", getattr(m.subject, \species", None))
    print(\Brain region:", getattr(m.brain_region, 
ame", None))
    # assets (list of Asset objects) — often contains morph files (h5/swcs)
    if getattr(m, \assets", None):
        for a in m.assets:
            print(\  Asset:", a.id, a.label, a.content_type, a.file_path if hasattr(a,  ile_path") else None)
    print("-\ * 40)
```

### 5) Common filters (examples)
- To narrow results, pass a query to `search_entity` (uses the same field names as the entity model):
```python
# morphologies for a specific MType label
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query={\mtype__pref_label": \SR_PC"}).all()

# morphologies in a given brain region id
morphs_in_region = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query={ rain_region__hierarchy_id": \YOUR_REGION_UUID"}).all()
```

### Notes and tips
- Use `m = client.search_entity(...).one()` if you expect a single result and want an error if multiple are returned.
- The `limit` parameter can be used to avoid downloading huge result sets at once. The `.all()` helper will page through results transparently.
- The exact attributes available on returned objects (e.g., `.assets`, `.subject`, `.mtype`) follow the entityschemata; inspect with `dir(m)` or print `m.__dict__` during development.
- See the entitysdk examples (e.g., examples/01_searching.ipynb) for more patterns (uploading assets, registering entities, and mtype classification).

If you want, I can:
- Provide a complete authenticated example tailored to your auth method (token / OIDC / config file).

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum — selected papers (2020–2025)

Below are recent, high-impact papers and preprints focused on neuronal morphology in cerebral cortex / cerebrum, returned by a literature search. I list a short summary, citation link (use the DOI or article URL), and any available figure image.

---

### 1) **Electrophysiology and Morphology of Human Cortical Supragranular Pyramidal Cells in a Wide Age Range**  
- Authors: Aller M., I.Wisden W. (eLife preprint)  
- Date: 2024-11-11  
- Summary: Large dataset of whole-cell recordings and 3D anatomical reconstructions of L2/3 human pyramidal neurons across infancy to elderly ages. Reports age-related changes in excitability and systematic spine analyses; provides data relevant for human cortical modeling and aging studies.  
- Link: [Electrophysiology and Morphology of Human Cortical Supragranular Pyramidal Cells in a Wide Age Range](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/100390v1)  
- Note: preprint with eLife assessment. I can attempt to read the full paper PDF if you want.

---

### 2) **Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry**  
- Author: Peng, Hanchuan et al. (Nature Communications)  
- Date: 2024-11-26  
- Summary: Massive whole-brain morphometry across 204 mouse brains (multi-modal imaging). Annotated ~182,497 cell bodies, characterized ~1,876 full neuronal morphologies and 2.63M axonal varicosities. Provides multi-scale quantification of neuronal diversity and stereotypy, and a large morphometry resource registered to the Allen CCF.  
- Link / DOI: [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6?error=cookies_not_supported&code=7bec93f7-e4da-41da-bd87-e0753db25493)  
- Image:  
  ![Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) **An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex**  
- Author: Ecker, Alexander S. et al. (Nature Communications)  
- Date: 2025-04-09  
- Summary: Data-driven, graph-based ML analysis of >30,000 excitatory neuron reconstructions from MICrONS EM volume (V1, AL, RL). Proposes morphology lies on continua (axes of variation) rather than discrete m-types for many layers, with layer- and area-specific trends. Useful for mapping dendritic organizational principles in cortex.  
- Link / DOI: [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w?error=cookies_not_supported&code=aa9276c8-ef16-46f6-9888-022b1a187b51)  
- Image:  
  ![Fig1](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4) **Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy**  
- Authors: Abdellah M., Hernando J., Eilemann S., Lapere S., Antille N., Markram H., Schürmann F. (eLife preprint)  
- Date: 2024-08-13  
- Summary: Large-scale, data-driven anatomical model for juvenile rat S1 cortex with 4.2M morphologically detailed neurons and 14.2B synapses. Focuses on anatomical placement and connectivity constraints — a major resource for simulations linking morphology to circuit function.  
- Link: [Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v1/pdf)  
- Note: dataset/subvolume available for community use.

---

### 5) **Cell class-specific long-range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker-related somatosensory cortices**  
- Authors: Aronoff R., Petersen C.C.H. (eLife preprint)  
- Date: 2024-05-17  
- Summary: Brain-wide mapping of long-range axonal outputs from genetically-defined excitatory neuron classes in whisker S1/S2 using light-sheet imaging + segmentation. Reports class- and layer-specific projection patterns, correlates anatomy with functional optogenetic mapping. Important for linking axonal morphology to network function.  
- Link: [Cell class-specific long-range axonal projections…](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602v1/pdf)

---

### 6) (emerging review) **Biophysical and computational insights from modeling human cortical pyramidal neurons**  
- Authors: Shapira S., Aizenbud I., Yoeli D., et al. (Frontiers in Neuroscience)  
- Date: 2025-07-09 (note: outside initial 2020–2024 window but included by the search)  
- Summary: Review/minireview integrating morphological and biophysical data from human cortical pyramidal neurons, and implications for modeling and computation. Useful for translating morphological differences into functional models.  
- Link / DOI: [10.3389/fnins.2025.1579715](https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/neuroscience/articles/10.3389/fnins.2025.1579715/pdf)

---

## Would you like any of the following?
- I can fetch the full text / PDFs for any of these (if publicly available) using the read-paper tool.  
- I can extract figures, specific methods (e.g., reconstruction pipeline), or morphological metrics (dendritic length, branch order, spine density) from any selected paper.  
- I can expand the list (more papers) or filter by species (mouse, rat, human), modality (EM, light-sheet, single-cell reconstructions), or topic (dendrites, axons, spines, development/aging).

- **June 27, 2025:** Changes to references, search tools, related citations, and sharing features.

simulation_tutorial.expected_output:
Here is a tutorial on how to simulate on the platform, specifically for simulating a single neuron model:

How to Simulate a Single Neuron Model on the Platform
Access Virtual Lab:

From the homepage, click the "Go to Virtual Lab" button.
Manage Projects:

Click on "Projects" in the left menu to see your projects.
Create a project if none exists.
Ensure you have credits in your project; transfer credits from your virtual lab if needed.
Build a Single Neuron Model:

Click on the "Build" column in the left panel.
Click the "Build" button in the single neuron tile.
Name your model, optionally add a description.
Select the brain region (e.g., primary somatosensory area).
Click "Start building."
Select a 3D reconstructed morphology (M model) and an existing electrical model (E model).
Filter morphologies by type (e.g., L5 TPC-A for thick tufted layer 5 pyramidal neuron).
Select the appropriate E model matching the morphology.
Save the created morph-electric model (M E model).
Simulate the Neuron Model:

Go back to your project homepage.
Click on the "Simulate" tab, then "Single Neuron."
Find your neuron model or search by name.
Click your model and press "New Simulation."
In the simulation window, pan, rotate, and zoom the neuron morphology.
Set experiment and simulation parameters.
Choose predefined current injection protocols or customize current steps.
Add multiple recording locations by clicking on the morphology or using the "Add Recording" button.
Press "Simulate" to run the simulation.
View and Save Results:

The "Results" tab will display recordings from selected locations.
Save recordings or save them to the library for later access.
You can watch the full tutorial video here:
How to simulate a single neuron model (Video)

If you want, I can guide you through any specific step or help you start a simulation on the platform.
simulation_tutorial.ai_response:
## Overview

You can run simulations on the Open Brain Platform at several scales (single neuron, pair, small microcircuit, microcircuit, region, system, whole-brain). The usual workflow is:

1. **Choose the simulation scale & goal** (e.g., reproduce firing of a cell, test synaptic connectivity in a microcircuit, run a network response to input).
2. **Gather or build required entities** (morphologies, e-models / e-types, me-models, circuit definitions, stimuli, recording probes).
3. **Create a simulation configuration** that describes the model, stimulation protocol, recording outputs and runtime parameters.
4. **Launch a simulation campaign** (which may contain many simulations or parameter sweeps).
5. **Monitor and retrieve results**, then analyze/visualize them (spikes, Vm traces, connectivity metrics, derived measures).
6. **Iterate**: change parameters or composition and re-run as needed.

Below I give a concise guide and recommendations for each step.

## Which simulation type should you pick?

| Scale | Typical use | Typical inputs |
|-------|-------------|----------------|
| **Single neuron** | Validate/characterize an e-model (ionic conductances) | Emodel (E-type), morphology, current injections, recordings |
| **Pair** | Study synaptic interactions, short-term plasticity | Two me-models/emodels, synapse definitions, stimulation schedule |
| **Small microcircuit** | Explore motif dynamics (3–20 neurons) | Set of me-models, explicit intrinsic connectivity, input patterns |
| **Microcircuit / Region** | Atlas-driven network behavior, population dynamics | Node sets, cell densities, extrinsic connectivity, synaptome |
| **System / Whole-brain** | Large-scale interactions (multi-region) | Connected microcircuits/regions, long-range connectivity |

## Prepare inputs (data & models)

- **Select models**: pick validated e-models or me-models from the platform (or upload your own). Use species/brain-region filters to match biological context.
- **Morphologies / cell-types**: ensure morphological exemplars match the e-type if using me-models.
- **Connectivity**: for circuits, define node sets and edge populations (intrinsic/extrinsic). The recommended tool sequence for circuit analysis is:
  - Get circuit structure first (use circuit metrics)
  - Then retrieve connectivity metrics (edge populations, probabilities, synapse counts)
- **Stimulation & recordings**: specify current injections, synaptic inputs, optogenetic stimuli, and which variables to record (Vm, spikes, calcium, synaptic currents).
- **Simulation runtime**: set duration, dt (time step), random seeds, and HPC/slurm parameters when applicable.

## Creating simulation configurations

- Simulation configs must fully describe the final state of the simulation (models, connectivity, inputs, outputs, runtime).  
- On this platform, you should use the simulation-config generator tool to produce the structured JSON configuration. Note: When you want a simulation JSON generated, the platform requires you to call the generator tool (I can prepare it for you if you provide the circuit/entity IDs and the desired final configuration).
- Typical config sections:
  - metadata (name, description, campaign id)
  - models (entity IDs for e-models / me-models)
  - network (node sets, connection rules or explicit edges)
  - stimuli (time course, targets)
  - probes (what variables to record and where)
  - runtime (tstop, dt, integration method)
  - outputs (which files to save, derived metrics)

## Launching and running

- Simulations can be run interactively (short single-neuron tests) or as part of a simulation campaign for parameter sweeps and batch jobs.
- Use reasonable time steps (dt) and tolerances depending on model stiffness; smaller dt increases accuracy and runtime.
- For larger circuits, use HPC/back-end resources provided by the platform; specify resource requests in the campaign config.

## Monitoring and results

- Typical outputs: spike rasters, Vm traces, per-cell quantities, connectivity-derived measures, and aggregated metrics (firing rates, synchrony).
- Check simulation logs for integration warnings, instabilities, or failed recordings.
- If results are large, download selectively (compressed traces, or derived CSV/NetCDF formats).

## Common pitfalls & tips

- Mismatch between morphology and e-model: verify that ionic channel distributions expected by the e-model are compatible with the morphology used.
- Unstable integration: if Vm explodes, try smaller dt, reduce strong currents, or use more stable integration settings.
- Connectivity errors: ensure node set IDs and edge-population IDs referenced in the config exist and match the circuit structure.
- Random seeds: set seeds for reproducibility; for sweeps, vary seeds systematically.
- Start small: validate single neurons and small motifs before running full microcircuit/region simulations.

## How I can help right now

- I can generate a complete simulation JSON configuration for a specific circuit or model. To do that I’ll need:
  - **Circuit/entity IDs** (UUIDs) you want to simulate (or tell me you want to build one)
  - The **scale/type** of simulation you want (single neuron, pair, microcircuit, etc.)
  - Key parameters: runtime (tstop, dt), stimuli, probes, any modifications to models (e.g., change gbar), and whether you want a campaign or a single run.

Important: when you want me to produce the actual simulation config JSON, I will call the platform generator tool to create it (the platform requires that). If you want me to prepare it now, provide the IDs and a full description of the desired final configuration and I will generate the config for you.

## Resources and next steps

- If you need a walkthrough of a specific simulation (e.g., simulate a Layer 5 pyramidal neuron current injection, or run a microcircuit response to Poisson background), tell me:
  - Which model/circuit IDs to use (or ask me to find available entities)
  - Exact stimulation and recording details
- If you want I can:
  - Draft a complete simulation config (and then call the generator tool to produce the JSON), or
  - Help you locate models/circuits on the platform (I can run EntityCore queries if you provide search terms).

Would you like me to prepare a simulation config now? If yes, specify the circuit/model IDs (or describe what to build) and the simulation parameters you want.

software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?
software_docs_obione.ai_response:
## Single-cell simulation example (obi-one)

Below is a minimal, self-contained example showing how to configure and run a single-cell (MEModel) simulation using **obi-one**. It follows the patterns from the examples in the obi-one repository: select a **MEModel** by ID, build an MEModel simulation form, validate it, and run it with the BlueCelluLab backend.

> Replace **<MEMODEL_ID>**, file paths and any numeric parameters with values you want to run.

### Python example

```python
# Single-cell simulation using obi-one
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# === 1. Parameters ===
MEMODEL_ID = "<MEMODEL_ID>\       # <<< replace with the MEModel entity ID
sim_duration = 3000.0             # total simulation time (ms)

# === 2. Build empty MEModel simulation config ===
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info (metadata)
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Single Cell Simulation",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current clamp"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# Timestamps: use RegularTimestamps as a reference for stimuli/recordings
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name=\RegularTimestamps")

# === 3. Stimulus: constant current clamp at soma ===
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,    # ms
    amplitude=0.5       # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput")

# === 4. Recordings: soma voltage ===
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name=\VoltageRecording")

time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name=\TimeWindowVoltageRecording")

# === 5. Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID ===
initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=MEMODEL_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(initialize, name=\initialize")

# === 6. Validate configuration ===
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated simulation config:")
print(validated_sim_conf)

# === 7. (Optional) Prepare a grid/scan wrapper if you need multiple runs
# Here we create a GridScanGenerationTask to produce a single run's files.
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX",
    output_root=Path("./obi-output/memodel_single_cell/grid_scan")
)
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)
# Execute generation locally via your db_client if required by your environment:
# grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)

# The path to the single simulation config:
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json"
print(\Simulation config path:", simulation_config_path)

# === 8. Run the simulation with BlueCelluLab backend ===
# (If you don't use grid_scan, you can save validated_sim_conf to JSON and pass that path.)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulator= luecellulab",  # or 
eurodamus"
    save_nwb=False
)

# After run completes, analyze outputs (e.g., with bluepysnap) as in the examples.
```

### Notes and pointers
- The example uses the form-based API: **MEModelSimulationScanConfig** and helpers like **ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus**, **SomaVoltageRecording**, and **MEModelFromID**.
- The run() function from **obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution** will invoke the simulator backend (BlueCelluLab by default in these examples).
- Replace **MEMODEL_ID** with a valid MEModel entity ID from your EntityCore project and adjust the output root / db_client calls to match your environment.

If you want, I can:
- Provide a shorter snippet that directly constructs and runs without the grid-scan wrapper, or
- Show how to select a MEModel interactively from available entities (example notebooks show that flow).
